connected_components.description: A resistor is used to set the PMBus address offset. The value of the resistor should be chosen from the 'MFR_BASE_ADDRESS' or 'MFR_BASE_ADDRESS_2' tables in the datasheet to achieve the desired unique PMBus address. The resistor is connected between the ADDR pin and the AGND pin.

implementation.connectivity: A resistor should be connected between the ADDR pin and AGND (Analog Ground). The value of this resistor determines the PMBus address offset.
implementation.detailed_description: The ADDR pin is used to program the base PMBus address of the device. A resistor connected between the ADDR pin and ground sets an offset from the default pre-configured MFR base address. This offset allows for multiple SiC45x devices with unique addresses to exist on a single bus.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of the ADDR pin is to set the PMBus address offset. The device reads an analog-to-digital converter (ADC) value from this pin during initialization to determine the offset. This offset is then combined with a base address to form the complete 7-bit PMBus address.
implementation.precautions: Do not leave the ADDR pin floating. A resistor must be connected to AGND to define the address offset. The choice of resistor value is critical for ensuring unique PMBus addresses for multiple devices on the same bus.

connected_components.connection: Connected between the VDD pin (22) and AGND (pin 7 or 16).
Connected between the RT/SYNC pin (17) and AGND (pin 7 or 16).
connected_components.value: Refer to 'RT/SYNC PIN and Mode of Switching Configuration' table

connected_components.connection: Connected between the VSET pin (15) and AGND (pin 7 or 16).
Connected between the ADDR pin (14) and AGND (pin 7 or 16).

implementation.connectivity: AGND pins should be connected to the system's analog ground. In most schematics, this will be the main ground plane. The VDD regulator requires a 1 µF decoupling capacitor connected between VDD and AGND. The RT/SYNC pin requires a resistor to AGND for frequency setting. The VSET pin requires a resistor to AGND for output voltage setting. The ADDR pin requires a resistor to AGND for PMBus address programming.
implementation.detailed_description: AGND (Analog Ground) serves as the reference ground for the analog control circuitry and signal processing within the SiC45x device. It provides a clean and stable ground reference for sensitive internal circuits, ensuring accurate operation of voltage regulation, monitoring, and communication interfaces.
implementation.functionality: Primarily serves as the analog ground reference. It is also the reference for the VDD (internal 5V regulator) output, requiring a decoupling capacitor to AGND. Additionally, it serves as the reference for the RT/SYNC pin when setting the switching frequency via an external resistor. The VSET pin also connects to AGND via a resistor to set the output voltage. The ADDR pin connects to AGND via a resistor to program the PMBus address. Finally, AGND is the return path for various internal analog signals.
implementation.precautions: It is crucial to keep the AGND potential clean and free from high-frequency noise. This is typically achieved by ensuring a solid connection to the system ground and by placing decoupling capacitors close to the AGND pins. Avoid routing high-current traces near AGND traces or planes. The AGND pins (7 and 16) should be connected together and to the system ground. The datasheet recommends a single point connection between AGND and PGND to maintain analog ground quietness.

BOOT.description: Bootstrap voltage for high side gate driver (referenced to PH)

connected_components.description: A ceramic capacitor is used as a bootstrap capacitor. It is connected between the BOOT pin (pin 6) and the PHASE pin (pin 4). The value of this capacitor is typically in the range of 100 nF to 1 μF and should be a low ESR ceramic type. The capacitor is charged when the low-side MOSFET is on, providing the necessary voltage to the BOOT pin to drive the high-side MOSFET when it is turned on.
connected_components.recommended_value: Refer to datasheet Electrical Characteristics or application notes for specific recommendations, but typically in the range of 100 nF to 1 μF.

implementation.connectivity: The BOOT pin should be connected to the PHASE pin through a bootstrap capacitor. This capacitor is used to charge up the bootstrap voltage when the low-side MOSFET is conducting.
implementation.detailed_description: The BOOT pin is the bootstrap voltage for the high-side gate driver. It is referenced to the PHASE pin.
implementation.functionality: The BOOT pin's primary function is to provide the necessary voltage to drive the high-side MOSFET. The voltage on the BOOT pin is generated by an external bootstrap capacitor connected between the BOOT and PHASE pins. This bootstrap voltage is typically higher than the PVCC supply, enabling the high-side driver to turn on the high-side MOSFET effectively.
precautions: The bootstrap capacitor and its associated connections should be placed as close as possible to the IC to minimize parasitic inductance and resistance.
The voltage rating of the bootstrap capacitor must be sufficient to handle the PVCC voltage plus the voltage drop across the low-side MOSFET.
Ensure the connection between the BOOT pin and the PHASE pin through the bootstrap capacitor is short and direct.
Do not leave the BOOT pin floating. It must always be connected to the bootstrap circuit.

EN.description: Enable pin. Active high 5 V logic level input

connected_components.description: A digital output pin from a microcontroller or a logic gate can be used to control the EN pin. This allows for programmatic control of the power converter's on/off state.
A simple switch can be connected to pull the EN pin high (to a logic '1' or VDD) to enable the device or to ground to disable it.

implementation.connectivity: The EN pin should be connected to a logic-level signal that controls the enable/disable state of the device. This can be from a microcontroller, a logic gate, or a switch.
implementation.detailed_description: The EN pin is an enable input for the SiC45x device. Driving this pin high enables the device, allowing it to operate. Grounding this pin turns the device off.
implementation.functionality: The EN pin serves a single primary function: enabling or disabling the device. It has an active-high logic level input.
precautions: The EN pin has no specific sequencing requirements with respect to input/output supplies, meaning it can be controlled independently.
Ensure the signal driving the EN pin is within the valid logic level range (0V to 5.5V as per recommended operating conditions).
Refer to the ON_OFF_CONFIGURATION (02h) PMBus command for detailed configuration options regarding the EN pin's behavior in conjunction with PMBus commands and power-up sequences.

connected_components.description: The GH pin is internally connected to the gate of the integrated high-side N-channel MOSFET within the SiC45x device. This MOSFET forms part of the synchronous buck converter's power stage.

implementation.connectivity: The GH pin is an output of the IC and should not be connected to any external components in a typical application schematic, other than potentially through parasitic inductance and capacitance of the trace.
implementation.detailed_description: The GH pin is the output of the high-side MOSFET gate driver. It directly controls the gate of the integrated high-side MOSFET in the power stage. When GH is high, the high-side MOSFET is turned on, allowing current to flow from PVIN to the SW node. When GH is low, the high-side MOSFET is turned off.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of the GH pin is to drive the gate of the high-side MOSFET.  Its voltage level directly corresponds to the on/off state of the high-side MOSFET.
precautions: The GH pin is a high-voltage, high-speed switching node output and should not be loaded or connected to external components that could draw significant current or introduce undesirable parasitic capacitance. Such connections could compromise the performance of the gate driver and the power stage.

Care should be taken in PCB layout to minimize the trace length and inductance between the GH pin and the internal high-side MOSFET gate to ensure proper switching characteristics and minimize voltage overshoot/undershoot.

connected_components.description: The GL pin is connected internally to the control logic and gate driver circuitry of the SiC45x device. This connection allows the IC to monitor the gate drive status of the low-side MOSFET.

implementation.connectivity: The GL pin is an output from the SiC45x device and is typically monitored internally. It does not require external connections in a standard schematic.
implementation.detailed_description: GL is the gate monitor for the low-side MOSFET. It provides feedback on the status of the low-side gate driver, allowing the device to monitor and control the switching behavior of the low-side MOSFET.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of the GL pin is to monitor the gate drive signal of the low-side MOSFET. This feedback is crucial for the internal control circuitry to ensure proper operation, timing, and protection mechanisms.
precautions: As GL is an internal monitoring pin, it should not be connected to any external components or signals. Doing so could disrupt the internal operation of the device and potentially lead to damage.
Ensure that the datasheet for the specific SiC45x device being used is consulted for any specific nuances or exceptions regarding the GL pin, although typically it is for internal monitoring only.

implementation.connectivity: Leave floating (unconnected).
implementation.detailed_description: The NC (Not Connected) pins on the SiC45x device are not used by Vishay and have no internal connection. They are reserved for potential future use or as placeholders and should not be connected to any external circuitry.
implementation.functionality: None
implementation.precautions: Do not connect these pins to any voltage source, ground, or signal. Connecting them could lead to unexpected behavior or damage to the device.

PGND.description: Power ground. Common return for internal MOSFETs

connected_components.description: The PGND pin should be connected to the main power ground plane of the PCB. This connection should be as short and wide as possible to minimize inductance and resistance.
The PGND pin is internally connected to the source terminals of the integrated high-side and low-side MOSFETs within the SiC45x device.

implementation.connectivity: PGND should be connected to the system's power ground. It's essential to have a robust and low-inductance connection to ground to ensure efficient operation and minimize noise.
implementation.detailed_description: PGND stands for Power Ground. It serves as the common return path for the internal power MOSFETs (both high-side and low-side) of the SiC45x DC/DC converter. This pin is critical for handling the high currents involved in the switching operation.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of PGND is to provide a low-impedance return path for the power stage current. It is directly connected to the source terminals of the internal MOSFETs.
precautions: Ensure a low-inductance and low-resistance connection between the PGND pin and the system ground plane. This is crucial for handling high switching currents and preventing voltage drops.
Avoid routing high-frequency switching signals (like SW nodes) over the PGND connection or the power ground plane. This can induce noise.
Multiple vias should be used to connect the PGND pad to the ground plane, especially in high-current applications, to improve thermal dissipation and reduce inductance.
The PGND plane should be carefully designed to handle the full switching current without excessive voltage drop or thermal stress.

PGOOD.description: Power good; open-drain output indicating VOUT is within set limits. Connect a pull up resistor typically 10 k to VDD

connected_components.description: A pull-up resistor is required. A typical value is 10 kΩ, but this can be adjusted based on system requirements and desired pull-up voltage. The other end of the resistor should be connected to a suitable voltage source (e.g., VDD).

implementation.connectivity: The PGOOD pin is an open-drain output, meaning it can only pull current to ground. To be useful, it requires an external pull-up resistor connected to a voltage source (typically VDD or a system voltage rail).
implementation.detailed_description: The PGOOD pin is an open-drain output that indicates when the output voltage (VOUT) is within the specified regulation limits set by the device's internal circuitry or PMBus commands. It signals the power good status of the DC/DC converter.
implementation.functionality: The PGOOD pin's functionality is primarily to signal power good status. It can be asserted (goes high or is pulled high) when VOUT is within the desired range and de-asserted (goes low or is released) when VOUT is outside of the acceptable limits (e.g., during startup, shutdown, or in a fault condition). The specific thresholds for asserting and de-asserting PGOOD are adjustable via PMBus commands (VOUT_PGOOD_ON and VOUT_PGOOD_OFF).
implementation.precautions: When connecting the PGOOD pin, ensure that the pull-up resistor is connected to a voltage level compatible with the system's logic inputs that will be monitoring this signal. Avoid connecting it directly to a voltage higher than the absolute maximum ratings of the pin or the monitoring circuitry. The PGOOD signal goes low when the output voltage is outside the set limits, so the monitoring circuitry should be designed to interpret a low state as a fault or invalid power condition.

PHASE.description: Phase node, return path of high side gate driver

connected_components.description: The source of the high-side MOSFET is connected to the PHASE pin.
The drain of the low-side MOSFET is connected to the PHASE pin.

implementation.connectivity: This pin is an internal node and is not typically connected to external components in a schematic, except for the intrinsic connection to the drain of the low-side MOSFET and source of the high-side MOSFET. However, it is crucial for the proper operation of the internal power stage.
implementation.detailed_description: The PHASE pin is the return path for the high-side gate driver. It is an internal node connected to the source of the high-side MOSFET and the drain of the low-side MOSFET.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of the PHASE pin is to serve as the return path for the gate drive current of the high-side MOSFET. It also monitors the phase node voltage, which is critical for the internal control loop and protection mechanisms.
implementation.precautions: The PHASE node experiences high-frequency switching transients. Proper PCB layout is critical to minimize noise and parasitic inductance on this node. Care must be taken to ensure the integrity of the internal connections to the MOSFETs. It should not be connected to external components unless specifically required for advanced layout techniques or diagnostics, and only with detailed understanding of the internal circuitry.

PVCC.description: Supply voltage for internal gate drive. PVCC is a LDO output. Connect a 4.7 μF decoupling capacitor to PGND

connected_components.connection: Connects between PVCC pin and PGND
connected_components.description: Decoupling capacitor

implementation.connectivity: Connect a decoupling capacitor from the PVCC pin to PGND.
implementation.detailed_description: PVCC is the supply voltage for the internal gate drive circuitry of the SiC45x microBuck converter. It is an output from an internal LDO.
implementation.functionality: Supply voltage for the internal gate drive.
implementation.precautions: Ensure the decoupling capacitor is placed very close to the IC to filter noise and provide maximum instantaneous driver current for the low side MOSFET during the switching cycle.

connected_components.description: This is the main DC power supply for the converter, ranging from 4.5 V to 20 V.

Ceramic capacitors (e.g., 2.2 μF) should be placed very close to the PVIN pins and PGND. Multiple capacitors of different values and packages are recommended to cover a wide range of frequencies. The datasheet mentions C_IN = 2.2 μF x 3 in the electrical characteristics figures, suggesting multiple ceramic capacitors are used.

implementation.connectivity: PVIN should be connected directly to the main input voltage source. For optimal performance and decoupling, it is recommended to connect input capacitors (both ceramic and bulk, if necessary) as close as possible to the PVIN pins and the power ground (PGND) pins.
implementation.detailed_description: PVIN (Pin 1, 2, 3, 34) is the input voltage for the power stage of the SiC45x DC/DC converter. This pin supplies the power to the integrated MOSFETs that perform the buck conversion.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of PVIN is to provide the input voltage required for the power stage operation. It is directly connected to the input voltage source (4.5 V to 20 V).
precautions: Ensure the input voltage stays within the recommended operating range of 4.5 V to 20 V to prevent damage to the device.
Proper placement and connection of input decoupling capacitors are crucial for stable operation and noise reduction. These capacitors should be placed as close as possible to the PVIN and PGND pins.
The PVIN pins are high current paths. The PCB layout should provide sufficient copper area and vias to handle the input current effectively, as detailed in the PCB Layout Recommendations section.

RT/SYNC.description: Clock synchronization pin. Frequency can be set by connecting a resistor to AGND. Pending on master / salve configuration, a clock can be send / receive via the pin

connected_components.description: Connects from the RT/SYNC pin to ground. The value of this resistor determines the default switching frequency according to the table in the datasheet. Examples: 2.87 kΩ for 600 kHz, 10 kΩ for 1000 kHz. This resistor should not be left open or shorted.

When operating in slave mode (in phase or 180° out of phase), an external clock signal is connected to the RT/SYNC pin. This signal synchronizes the device's switching. If the external clock comes from a SiC45x master, the RRT value on the master and slave should be the same.

implementation.connectivity: The RT/SYNC pin should be connected to ground via an external resistor (RRT) to set the switching frequency. This resistor value determines the default frequency, which can be overridden by PMBus commands. For synchronization applications, this pin also serves as an input/output for the clock signal depending on the master/slave configuration.
implementation.detailed_description: The RT/SYNC pin is a versatile pin used for two primary functions: setting the switching frequency and synchronizing the device's operation with an external clock signal. It plays a role in both standalone operation and master/slave configurations for synchronization.

functionality.description: By connecting an external resistor (RRT) from the RT/SYNC pin to ground, the switching frequency of the device is set. A small DC current (less than 1 mA) is injected into the pin during power-up to read this resistor value and determine the default switching frequency. This setting can be overridden by a PMBus command.

When configured as a master device via a PMBus command, the RT/SYNC pin outputs a 50% duty cycle clock signal. This signal is in phase with the device's switching node and can be used to drive external slave devices.

When configured as a slave device in phase via a PMBus command, the RT/SYNC pin receives an external clock signal. The device synchronizes its switching node to be in phase with this external clock signal. The external clock signal can come from a master SiC45x device. If an external clock is present, it overrides the frequency set by the RT/SYNC resistor.

When configured as a slave device 180° out of phase via a PMBus command, the RT/SYNC pin receives an external clock signal. The device synchronizes its switching node to be 180° out of phase with this external clock signal. The external clock signal can come from a master SiC45x device. If an external clock is present, it overrides the frequency set by the RT/SYNC resistor.
functionality.function: Clock Synchronization (Slave Mode - 180° Out of Phase)

precautions: The RT/SYNC pin should not be left open or shorted. An external resistor is always required for frequency setting.
In master mode, the RT/SYNC pin outputs a clock signal after power-up and VDD is above its UVLO threshold. Ensure this output is not loaded inappropriately.
In slave mode, the external clock signal overrides the frequency set by the RT/SYNC resistor. Ensure the external clock is within the specified frequency range (300 kHz to 1500 kHz).
When synchronizing multiple SiC45x devices, the RT/SYNC resistor value on the master and slave devices should be the same.
The switching frequency set by the external resistor can be overridden by the FREQUENCY_SWITCH PMBus command.
The mode of switching configuration (standalone, master, slave in phase, slave 180° out of phase) is determined by the INTERLEAVE PMBus command.

SALRT.description: PMBus alert. Connect to external host interface if desired

connected_components.description: A resistor connected from the SALRT pin to the system's logic supply voltage (e.g., VDD). This is necessary for the open-drain output to drive a high logic level when no alert is active. A typical value is 10 kΩ.
The SALRT pin connects to an interrupt or alert input pin on the host microcontroller or processor, allowing it to receive alert notifications from the SiC45x device.

implementation.connectivity: The SALRT pin should be connected to the host system's interrupt or alert input line. Since it is an open-drain output, it requires a pull-up resistor to a logic-compatible voltage level (typically VDD or a system voltage) for proper signaling. The value of the pull-up resistor should be chosen based on the system's bus capacitance and desired signaling speed, but a common value is 10 kΩ.
implementation.detailed_description: The SALRT pin is a PMBus alert output. It is designed to signal an alert condition to an external host interface when certain fault or warning conditions occur within the SiC45x device. This pin allows for asynchronous notification of issues, enabling the host to take appropriate action without constant polling.
implementation.functionality: The SALRT pin functions as an open-drain output. It can be configured via PMBus commands to signal various types of alerts, including fault conditions and warning thresholds. The specific conditions that trigger the SALRT pin are programmable through PMBus commands and are reflected in the status registers.
precautions: Ensure the pull-up resistor value is appropriate for the system's bus capacitance to avoid signal degradation.
The voltage level of the pull-up resistor should be compatible with the host system's logic levels.
Configure the specific alert conditions that trigger the SALRT pin using PMBus commands to avoid unnecessary interruptions.

SCL.description: PMBus clock. Connect to external host interface

connected_components.connection_details: Connect the SCL output of the master device to the SCL input of the SiC45x.
connected_components.description: The master device initiates and controls the PMBus communication, generating the clock signal on its SCL output.

implementation.connectivity: The SCL pin should be connected to the SCL pin of the master device. For a multi-drop PMBus configuration, it should be connected in parallel to the SCL pins of all other PMBus devices on the bus.
implementation.detailed_description: SCL (Serial Clock) is the clock line for the PMBus (Power Management Bus) interface. It is used to synchronize the data transfer between the master (typically a host controller) and the slave device (the SiC45x converter). The clock signal dictates the timing for data bits being transmitted and received on the SDA line.
implementation.functionality: The SCL pin serves as the clock signal for the PMBus communication. It is an input pin controlled by the master device to regulate the data transfer rate. The frequency of the SCL signal determines the bus speed. The datasheet mentions PMBus 1.3 compliant with 1 MHz bus speed, implying the SCL signal can operate up to this frequency.
precautions: The SCL line, along with the SDA line, requires pull-up resistors. The value of these resistors depends on the bus speed and the total capacitance of the bus. Typical values range from 1 kΩ to 10 kΩ. The datasheet does not explicitly specify the pull-up resistor value for SCL, but it's a standard PMBus requirement.
Ensure that the SCL signal integrity is maintained, especially in systems with multiple devices or long bus traces. Signal reflections and noise can be an issue at higher bus speeds (up to 1 MHz).
The SiC45x supports PMBus 1.3 with a 1 MHz bus speed. Ensure that the master device is also capable of operating at this speed if maximum performance is desired.
The SCL pin is susceptible to noise and should be routed carefully, keeping traces short and away from high-current power paths. Shielding may be beneficial in noisy environments.

SDA.description: PMBus data. Connect to external host interface

connected_components.description: The SDA pin of the SiC45x device connects to the SDA pin of the PMBus master controller. This enables bidirectional communication for sending commands and receiving data.

As per I2C/PMBus specifications, the SDA line requires pull-up resistors to the logic supply voltage (VDD). The value of these resistors depends on the bus speed, bus capacitance, and the number of devices on the bus, but typically range from 2.2 kΩ to 10 kΩ.

implementation.connectivity: The SDA pin should be connected to the SDA pin of the PMBus master controller (e.g., a microcontroller or a dedicated PMBus controller). It is part of the I2C communication bus, and multiple devices can share the same SDA line through proper addressing.
implementation.detailed_description: SDA is the PMBus data pin, used for bidirectional data transfer during communication with an external host system over the PMBus interface.
implementation.functionality: This pin is used for both sending and receiving data for PMBus commands and telemetry information. It acts as a data line in the I2C-like PMBus protocol.
precautions: Ensure that the SDA line is properly terminated with pull-up resistors as required by the PMBus/I2C protocol.
Keep the trace length for the SDA line as short as possible to minimize noise and signal integrity issues, especially at higher bus speeds.
Properly address the SiC45x device on the PMBus to avoid bus conflicts if multiple devices are connected to the same SDA/SCL lines.
Ensure that the logic levels of the SDA signal are compatible with the PMBus master controller.

connected_components.description: A power inductor is connected between the SW pin and the output voltage rail (VOUT). The value of the inductor is chosen based on the desired switching frequency, input voltage, output voltage, and output current to ensure proper operation and minimize ripple.

A bootstrap capacitor is connected between the PHASE pin and the BOOT pin. This capacitor is used to generate the necessary voltage to drive the high-side MOSFET gate. The SW pin is indirectly involved as it is connected to the PHASE pin.

While not directly connected to the SW pin, the output capacitors are connected across the output voltage rail and are essential for filtering the ripple generated by the switching action at the SW node.

implementation.connectivity: In a schematic, the SW pin is connected to one side of the external power inductor. The other side of the power inductor is connected to the output voltage rail (VOUT). The SW pin also connects to the PHASE pin via the external bootstrap capacitor. It is important to keep the traces connected to the SW pin as short and wide as possible to minimize parasitic inductance and resistance.
implementation.detailed_description: The SW (Switch Node) pin is the primary output of the integrated switching MOSFETs (both high-side and low-side). It acts as the connection point to the external power inductor and represents the switching point where the output voltage is generated.
implementation.functionality: The SW pin's primary function is to provide the switched output voltage. It is the node where the high-side MOSFET connects to the inductor during the on-time, and where the low-side MOSFET connects to ground during its on-time (allowing current to flow through the inductor to the output). It is also the point where the switching current flows, making it a critical node for power delivery and also a source of potential noise.
precautions: The SW node is a high-current, high-frequency switching node and can be a source of electromagnetic interference (EMI). Careful PCB layout is crucial to minimize noise. This includes keeping the traces connected to SW short, wide, and avoiding routing them under sensitive analog components.

The SW node experiences significant voltage and current swings. Ensure that the PCB traces and copper planes connected to the SW pin are adequately sized to handle the current and minimize voltage drops.
Avoid placing vias on the SW pad itself as they can act as noise sources and may lead to assembly issues.
The SW node should not be used for analog signal routing due to its high noise content.

VDD.description: Internal 5 V circuits supply voltage. VDD is a LDO output, connect a 1 μF decoupling capacitor to AGND

connected_components.connection: Connected between the VDD pin and AGND.

implementation.connectivity: Should be connected to a 1 μF decoupling capacitor to AGND.
implementation.detailed_description: The VDD pin is the supply voltage for the internal 5V circuits and driver supply. It is an output from an internal LDO.
implementation.functionality: Serves as the power supply for internal control circuitry and gate drivers.
implementation.precautions: A 1 μF decoupling capacitor must be connected to AGND to ensure stable operation of the internal circuits and driver supply.

connected_components.description: PVIN (Pin 1, 2, 3, 34) is the input voltage for the power stage. The VIN pin is internally connected to PVIN, so they should be tied together in the schematic.

implementation.connectivity: This pin should be connected to PVIN.
implementation.detailed_description: VIN is the internal driver supply voltage for the SiC45x. It is used to power the gate drive circuitry for the internal MOSFETs.
implementation.functionality: This pin serves as the supply voltage for the internal driver circuits. It is internally connected to PVIN, which is the main input voltage for the power stage.
precautions: Ensure that the voltage applied to VIN (and PVIN) is within the recommended operating conditions (4.5 V to 20 V).
Proper decoupling is essential for stable operation. Refer to the PCB layout recommendations for guidance on decoupling capacitor placement and values.

VSEN+.description: Remote sense amplifier positive input connect to output

connected_components.description: The point of load where the output voltage needs to be precisely regulated. VSEN+ is connected to the positive terminal of the load.

VSEN- is the negative input of the differential sense amplifier and should be connected to the ground reference (VOUT-) of the load. The differential voltage between VSEN+ and VSEN- is used for feedback.

implementation.connectivity: VSEN+ should be connected directly to the positive output voltage rail (VOUT+) at the load. It is used in conjunction with the VSEN- pin.  For optimal performance, this connection should be a dedicated trace to minimize impedance and voltage drop.
implementation.detailed_description: The VSEN+ pin is the positive input for the differential output voltage sense amplifier. This amplifier is used to accurately monitor the output voltage (VOUT) and compensate for any voltage drops across the power delivery path, such as traces or connectors. By sensing the output voltage directly at the load, the regulator can maintain a precise and stable output voltage at the point of load.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of VSEN+ is to serve as the positive input to a differential amplifier that measures the output voltage. It is designed to be connected to the output voltage rail as close to the load as possible. In conjunction with VSEN-, it allows the converter to implement remote voltage sensing for improved regulation accuracy.
precautions: Connect VSEN+ as close to the load as possible to accurately sense the voltage delivered to the load. Avoid connecting it at the output capacitor or the DC/DC converter pins if significant trace impedance is present.

Ensure the trace connecting VSEN+ to the load is a dedicated differential pair with VSEN- to minimize noise pickup and voltage drop. Keep these traces short and away from high-current switching nodes (SW, PHASE).

The common-mode voltage range for the VSEN+ pin is specified in the datasheet (typically from -0.2 V to +12 V). Ensure the output voltage does not exceed this range during normal operation or fault conditions.

If the output voltage is set using an external resistor on the VSET pin and PMBus is not used, the output voltage accuracy will be influenced by the impedance of the traces connecting VSEN+ and VSEN-. If higher accuracy is required without PMBus control, consider using a resistor divider from the output to VSET, but ensure the trace impedance is accounted for.

VSEN-.description: Remote sense amplifier negative input connect to output ground

connected_components.description: This is the ground reference at the output of the DC/DC converter, typically connected to the system ground plane.

implementation.connectivity: Connect to the output ground.
implementation.detailed_description: The VSEN- pin is the negative input of the remote sense amplifier. This amplifier is used to provide precise output voltage regulation by sensing the voltage directly at the output load, compensating for any voltage drops across traces or connectors. The VSEN- pin should be connected to the output ground.
implementation.functionality: This pin serves as the negative input for the differential output voltage sense amplifier.
implementation.precautions: Ensure that the VSEN- connection is made at the point of load to accurately sense the output voltage and compensate for voltage drops. Avoid connecting it to the device's power ground (PGND) if there is a significant voltage difference or impedance between the two grounds.

VSET.description: Output voltage set point by connecting a resistor from VSET to AGND

connected_components.description: Connect a resistor from the VSET pin to AGND to set the output voltage and related parameters. The specific resistance value should be chosen based on the desired VOUT from the 'OUTPUT VOLTAGE SETTINGS' table. If PMBus is used for VOUT control, this pin should be shorted to AGND or left open, meaning no resistor is connected between VSET and AGND in that configuration.

implementation.connectivity:
To set the output voltage, warning/fault limits, and VOUT_SCALE_LOOP using an external resistor, connect a resistor from the VSET pin to AGND. The value of this resistor determines the VOUT and other related parameters according to the 'OUTPUT VOLTAGE SETTINGS' and 'VOUT RELATED WARNINGS AND FAULTS' tables. 
If the output voltage is to be set via PMBus, the VSET pin should be shorted to AGND or left open.
implementation.detailed_description: The VSET pin is used to set the output voltage (VOUT) of the DC/DC converter. It can also be used in conjunction with external components to set warning and fault voltage limits, and to define the VOUT_SCALE_LOOP value. When output voltage is set by PMBus, this pin should be shorted to AGND or left open.
implementation.functionality:
The VSET pin's functionality depends on how it is connected:
- Connected to AGND via a resistor: Sets the output voltage, warning/fault limits, and VOUT_SCALE_LOOP. This method is used when PMBus is not the primary control for VOUT.
- Shorted to AGND or left open: Allows VOUT to be set via PMBus commands, with independent adjustment of warning and fault limits. This is the preferred method when using the PMBus interface for VOUT control.
precautions: When using an external resistor to set VOUT, the accuracy of the output voltage might be less precise compared to setting it via PMBus. Contact Vishay for details on using a resistor divider for output voltage setting if a different voltage than listed is required without PMBus.

Do not leave the VSET resistor open or short if it's intended to set the output voltage via resistor programming; refer to the relevant tables for specific resistor values. If PMBus is used for VOUT setting, ensure the pin is either shorted to AGND or left open as specified.

fields.description: Turn the regulator output on or off.
fields.name: OPERATION_ON_OFF

fields.description: Controls how the output is turned off.

digital_physical_map.0: Output is turned off immediately and power off sequence commands ignored
digital_physical_map.1: Regulator turns off following the TOFF_DELAY and TOFF_FALL command

fields.name: OPERATION_OFF_B

fields.description: Sets the output voltage source when in margin mode.
fields.name: OPERATION_MARGIN

fields.description: Fault handling behavior when caused by margining.

digital_physical_map.1: Faults caused by selecting VOUT_MARGIN_HIGH or VOUT_MARGIN_LOW as nominal output voltage source are ignored
digital_physical_map.2: Faults caused by selecting VOUT_MARGIN_HIGH or VOUT_MARGIN_LOW as nominal output voltage source are acted upon according to VOUT_OV_FAULT_RESPONSE and VOUT_UV_FAULT_RESPONSE

fields.name: OPERATION_MRGNFLT

fields.description: Controls power-up behavior.

digital_physical_map.0: Regulator powers up any time power is present regardless of EN pin state
digital_physical_map.1: Regulator does not power up until commanded by CONTROL_EN pin and OPERATION command

fields.name: ON_OFF_CONFIGURATION_PU

fields.description: Enables response to the 'on' bit in the OPERATION command.

digital_physical_map.0: Regulator ignores the 'on' bit in the OPERATION command
digital_physical_map.1: Regulator responds to the 'on' bit in the OPERATION command

fields.name: ON_OFF_CONFIGURATION_CMD

fields.description: Controls the use of the EN pin.

digital_physical_map.0: Regulator ignores the EN pin. Power conversion controlled only by OPERATION command
digital_physical_map.1: Regulator requires EN pin to be asserted to start the unit

fields.name: ON_OFF_CONFIGURATION_EN

fields.description: Sets the polarity of the EN signal.
fields.name: ON_OFF_CONFIGURATION_ENPOL

fields.description: Controls how the device turns off when EN signal is used.

digital_physical_map.0: Regulator turns off following TOFF_DELAY and TOFF_FALL command

fields.name: ON_OFF_CONFIGURATION_OFFB1

fields.description: Controls write access to PMBus commands.

digital_physical_map.1: Disable all writes except to WRITE_PROTECT, OPERATION_ON_OFF_CONFIG, and VOUT_COMMAND commands
digital_physical_map.2: Disable all writes except to WRITE_PROTECT and OPERATION commands
digital_physical_map.4: Disable all writes except to WRITE_PROTECT command

fields.name: WRITE_PROTECT_WTPRT

fields.description: Indicates if Packet Error Checking is supported.
fields.name: CAPABILITY_PEC

fields.description: Maximum supported bus speed.

digital_physical_map.2: Maximum supported bus speed is 1 MHz

fields.name: CAPABILITY_SPD

fields.description: Indicates if SMBus Alert Response Protocol is supported.

digital_physical_map.1: The unit has SMBALERT# pin and supports SMBus alert response protocol

fields.name: CAPABILITY_ALRT

fields.description: Numeric data format.

digital_physical_map.0: Numeric data is in LINEAR11, LINEAR16, or DIRECT format

fields.name: CAPABILITY_NFMT

fields.description: Indicates if AVSBUS is supported.
fields.name: CAPABILITY_AVS

fields.description: Sets the mode for VOUT related commands.

digital_physical_map.0: The unit uses ULINEAR16 format for VOUT related commands

fields.name: VOUT_MODE_MODE

fields.description: Exponent for linear data mode in VOUT commands.

digital_physical_map.23: Exponent equals -9 for VOUT related commands

fields.name: VOUT_MODE_EXP

fields.description: Sets the output voltage. VOUT_SET = VOUT_COMMAND * 2^N
fields.name: VOUT_COMMAND

fields.description: Applies a fixed offset voltage to the output voltage command value. Delta Voltage = (Delta V * 2^N) / VOUT_SCALE_LOOP
fields.name: VOUT_TRIM

fields.description: Sets an upper limit on the output voltage.
fields.name: VOUT_MAX

fields.description: Sets the output voltage for 'margin high' operation.
fields.name: VOUT_MARGIN_HIGH

fields.description: Sets the output voltage for 'margin low' operation.
fields.name: VOUT_MARGIN_LOW

fields.description: Exponent for VOUT_TRANSITION_RATE.
fields.name: VOUT_TRANSITION_RATE_EXP

fields.description: Mantissa for VOUT_TRANSITION_RATE.
fields.name: VOUT_TRANSITION_RATE_MAN

fields.description: Scales VOUT_COMMAND and sense differential output voltage.
fields.name: VOUT_SCALE_LOOP

fields.description: Sets the switching frequency.
fields.name: FREQUENCY_SWITCH

fields.description: Input voltage threshold to start power conversion.
fields.name: VIN_ON

fields.description: Input voltage threshold to stop power conversion.
fields.name: VIN_OFF

fields.description: Sets the mode of switching frequency and phase.
fields.name: INTERLEAVE

fields.description: Output voltage threshold for overvoltage fault.
fields.name: VOUT_OV_FAULT_LIMIT

fields.description: Output overvoltage fault response.

digital_physical_map.3: Device output is disabled while fault is present, resumes when fault condition no longer exists

fields.name: VOUT_OV_FAULT_RESPONSE_OVRSP

fields.description: Output overvoltage fault type.

digital_physical_map.4: Device output is disabled while fault is present, resumes when fault condition no longer exists
digital_physical_map.5: Device output is disabled while fault is present, resumes when fault condition no longer exists
digital_physical_map.6: Device output is disabled while fault is present, resumes when fault condition no longer exists
digital_physical_map.7: Device output is disabled while fault is present, resumes when fault condition no longer exists

fields.name: VOUT_OV_FAULT_RESPONSE_OVRTY

fields.description: Delay for output overvoltage fault response.

fields.description: Output voltage threshold for overvoltage warning.
fields.name: VOUT_OV_WARN_LIMIT

fields.description: Output voltage threshold for undervoltage warning.
fields.name: VOUT_UV_WARN_LIMIT

fields.description: Output voltage threshold for undervoltage fault.
fields.name: VOUT_UV_FAULT_LIMIT

fields.description: Output undervoltage fault response.

digital_physical_map.2: Device output is disabled while fault is present, resumes when fault condition no longer exists. Does not attempt to restart.

fields.name: VOUT_UV_FAULT_RESPONSE_UVRSP

fields.description: Output undervoltage fault type.

digital_physical_map.4: Device output is disabled while fault is present, resumes when fault condition no longer exists
digital_physical_map.5: Device output is disabled while fault is present, resumes when fault condition no longer exists
digital_physical_map.6: Device output is disabled while fault is present, resumes when fault condition no longer exists
digital_physical_map.7: Device output is disabled while fault is present, resumes when fault condition no longer exists

fields.name: VOUT_UV_FAULT_RESPONSE_UVRTY

fields.description: Delay for output undervoltage fault response.
fields.name: VOUT_UV_FAULT_RESPONSE_UVDLY

fields.description: Output current threshold for overcurrent fault. Units: A
fields.name: IOUT_OC_FAULT_LIMIT

fields.description: Output overcurrent fault response.

digital_physical_map.1: Device continues operation for 128 consecutive OC cycles and then shut down. Waiting for 20 ms, it hiccups until fault condition no longer exists
digital_physical_map.2: Device continues operation for 8 consecutive OC cycles then shut down without delay
digital_physical_map.3: Device continues operation for 32 consecutive OC cycles then shut down without delay
digital_physical_map.4: Device continues operation for 128 consecutive OC cycles then shut down without delay
digital_physical_map.5: Device continues operation for 512 consecutive OC cycles then shut down without delay
digital_physical_map.6: Device continues operation and never shuts down when OCP happens

fields.name: IOUT_OC_FAULT_RESPONSE_OCRSP

fields.description: Number of consecutive pulse-by-pulse OC counts before fault.

digital_physical_map.7: Device continues operation indefinitely without shutdown

fields.name: IOUT_OC_FAULT_RESPONSE_OCCYCL

fields.description: Delay time between shutdown and next restart attempt.
fields.name: IOUT_OC_FAULT_RESPONSE_OCDLY

fields.description: Output current threshold for overcurrent warning. Units: A
fields.name: IOUT_OC_WARN_LIMIT

fields.description: Temperature threshold for overtemperature fault. Units: °C
fields.name: OT_FAULT_LIMIT

fields.description: Overtemperature fault response.

digital_physical_map.3: Device output is disabled while fault is present, resumes when fault condition no longer exists. Attempts to restart continuously.

fields.name: OT_FAULT_RESPONSE_OTRSP

fields.description: Overtemperature fault type.

digital_physical_map.4: Device output is disabled while fault is present, resumes when fault condition no longer exists
digital_physical_map.5: Device output is disabled while fault is present, resumes when fault condition no longer exists
digital_physical_map.6: Device output is disabled while fault is present, resumes when fault condition no longer exists
digital_physical_map.7: Device output is disabled while fault is present, resumes when fault condition no longer exists

fields.name: OT_FAULT_RESPONSE_OTRTY

fields.description: Delay for overtemperature fault response.
fields.name: OT_FAULT_RESPONSE_OTDLY

fields.description: Temperature threshold for overtemperature warning. Units: °C
fields.name: OT_WARN_LIMIT

fields.description: Input voltage threshold for overvoltage fault. Units: V
fields.name: VIN_OV_FAULT_LIMIT

fields.description: Input overvoltage fault response.

digital_physical_map.2: Device output is disabled while fault is present. Does not attempt to restart. Output remains disabled until fault is cleared.

fields.name: VIN_OV_FAULT_RESPONSE_VIOVRSP

fields.description: Input overvoltage fault type.

digital_physical_map.4: Device output is disabled while fault is present. Does not attempt to restart. Output remains disabled until fault is cleared.
digital_physical_map.5: Device output is disabled while fault is present. Does not attempt to restart. Output remains disabled until fault is cleared.
digital_physical_map.6: Device output is disabled while fault is present. Does not attempt to restart. Output remains disabled until fault is cleared.
digital_physical_map.7: Device output is disabled while fault is present. Does not attempt to restart. Output remains disabled until fault is cleared.

fields.description: Time from start condition until output voltage starts to rise. Units: ms
fields.name: TON_DELAY

fields.description: Time from output start to rise until voltage enters regulation band. Units: ms
fields.name: TON_RISE

fields.description: Upper limit on time to power up output without reaching UV fault limit. Units: ms
fields.name: TON_MAX_FAULT_LIMIT

digital_physical_map.0: Device shuts down. Does not attempt to restart.
digital_physical_map.1: Device shuts down. Attempts to restart continuously.
